WARNING.SERVER-LICENSE-ISSUE-ENDPOINT-ERROR: The endpoint did not respond when checking the license last time. Further checks will be performed, but for now the license is assumed to be invalid.
WARNING.SERVER-LICENSE-ISSUE-LICENSE-INVALID: Application is in read-only mode due to an invalid license on the endpoint server.
WARNING.SERVER-LICENSE-ISSUE-LICENSE-NOT-FOUND: Application is in read-only mode since no license could be found on the endpoint server.
WARNING.SERVER-LICENSE-ISSUE-LICENSE-INVALID-DAT: Application is in read-only mode since the license date on the Alfresco Process Services endpoint server isn't valid (either expired or has a start date that hasn't yet occurred).

MONITORING.NOT-ENOUGH-DATA: The node is in an unknown state. This could be because the node hasn't finished joining the cluster or it hasn't sent enough data yet to display here.
MONITORING.SUITE-INFORMATION: This is an instance of the Process Services Suite, version {{bpmSuiteMajorVersion}}.{{bpmSuiteMinorVersion}}.{{bpmSuiteRevisionVersion}} (edition '{{bpmSuiteEdition}}')

MONITORING.REST-ENDPOINTS: REST endpoints timings (duration unit = seconds, rate unit = calls/second)
MONITORING.ELASTIC-SEARCH-STATE-DESCRIPTION: a red status indicates that the specific shard is not allocated in the cluster, yellow means that the primary shard is allocated but replicas are not, and green means that all shards are allocated

CLUSTER.NAME: Name:
CLUSTER.ENDPOINT-HELP: The endpoint configuration (each cluster has only one) needs to point to a REST installation. This endpoint retrieves and manages the data used in the other sections (for example deployments, process definitions, and so on) of this application.
CLUSTER.PROCESS-ENGINE-HELP: This section allows you to define a 'master configuration' for the cluster. All instances in the cluster will use this configuration when they boot up (if the cluster config jar is on the classpath or if the corresponding properties are set). If not set, the instances will use their local configuration files.

SELECT-MASTER.TITLE: Select master configuration
SELECT-MASTER.MESSAGE: Are you sure you want to select '{{name}}' as master configuration?

DELETE-MASTER.TITLE: Delete master configuration
DELETE-MASTER.MESSAGE: Are you sure you want to delete this master configuration?

GENERATE-JAR.TITLE: Generate Cluster Configuration jar
GENERATE-JAR.MESSAGE: It is important that all members of the same cluster use the same settings.
GENERATE-JAR.LINK-MESSAGE: To facilitate this, a Java Archive jar (jar) can be downloaded by following the link below. This jar contains the configuration needed for a Process Services instance to communicate with the Process Services Admin Application.The jar simply needs to be put on the classpath and will be automatically used.
GENERATE-JAR.ADMIN-APP-URL: The following field is the base URL which will be used to send information back to this Admin Application. Change it if, for some reason, the URL does not match the URL used to view this web UI.

EDIT-ENDPOINT.TITLE: Edit endpoint configuration
EDIT-ENDPOINT.ENDPOINT-PASSWORD-HELP: Leave blank to keep current password
EDIT-ENDPOINT.ERROR-500: Error: server error. Check server logs.

DELETE-CLUSTER-CONFIG.TITLE: Delete cluster configuration
DELETE-CLUSTER-CONFIG.WARNING: When a cluster configuration is deleted, note that you also should remove the configuration jar (or properties file) for this cluster configuration from the classpath of the nodes.
DELETE-CLUSTER-CONFIG.ERROR-ONLY-ONE-CLUSTER-CONFIG: Cannot delete this cluster configuration: there needs to be one cluster configuration at minimum and this is the only cluster configuration defined in the system.

EDIT-CLUSTER-CONFIG.GROUP-HELP: Each cluster needs to have a unique name. Each of the engine instances will need to provide this cluster name to join the cluster.
EDIT-CLUSTER-CONFIG.NAME: Name
EDIT-CLUSTER-CONFIG.SECURITY-HELP: Each cluster needs to have a user name and password. Each of the Process Services engine instances that want to interchange data with the Process Services Admin Application will need to provide these credentials in their communication.
EDIT-CLUSTER-CONFIG.ACTIVITI-HELP: When you enable master configuration, process instances that are members of this cluster boot up using the master configuration.
EDIT-CLUSTER-CONFIG.METRICS-HELP: Each Process Services instance which is a member of this cluster will send metrics (for example JVM and usage metrics) back to the Process Services Admin App. The following setting defines how frequent these metrics are gathered and sent.
EDIT-CLUSTER-CONFIG.ERROR-NAME-TAKEN: Cluster name already used. Choose another one.
EDIT-CLUSTER-CONFIG.ERROR-USER-TAKEN: Cluster user name already used. Choose another one.

EDIT-CONFIG.NAME: Name
EDIT-CONFIG.JDBC-JNDI-HELP: Fill this in (ignoring the settings above) if the datasource is configured in an application server and exposed through Jndi.
EDIT-CONFIG.SCHEMA-UPDATE-HELP: It is advisable to leave this set to 'false', and upgrade the database schema using the SQL scripts. If set to 'true' the first node in the cluster to boot up will auto-upgrade the schema. This could cause issues when multiple nodes boot up at the same time since data definition is often not transactional.
EDIT-CONFIG.NR-OF-JOB-NODES-HELP: Each Process Services engine instance has a job executor component, which is responsible for executing background tasks such as timers and async continuations of business processes. It is advisable, however, to only have a small number (one, two or more for very high load scenarios) of jobexecutors activated. The value of this setting will be used to activate or deactivate job executors as necessary in the cluster.
EDIT-CONFIG.PROCESS-DEF-CACHE-LIMIT-HELP: The maximum number of (parsed) process definitions that is kept in memory. Parsing a process definition is resource-intensive, so it is advisable to have a large enough cache while not using too much memory (default: unlimited).
EDIT-CONFIG.ID-BLOCK-SIZE-HELP: The number of database ID’s that a Process Services engine reserves for use when creating new entities (default: 100). When all ID’s have been used, a new block is reserved in the database.
EDIT-CONFIG.ENABLE-JOB-TWEAKING-HELP: The job executor is the component responsible for, amongst other things, executing timers and asynchronous continuations (referred to as 'jobs') of business processes.
EDIT-CONFIG.MAX-JOBS-PER-ACQUISITION-HELP: The job executor works in two phases: first, jobs are 'acquired' by locking jobs for a certain amount of time (to avoid conflicts between multiple job executors). In the second phase, the acquired jobs are executed by (typically) a separate threadpool. This value determines how many job are acquired per query for phase 1. When more than one job executor is active in a cluster, it is advised to set this value to 1 to avoid deadlocks. Default value is 1.
EDIT-CONFIG.JOB-WAIT-TIME-HELP: The time (in ms) that is waited after all jobs have been executed or no jobs have been found. This is to avoid hitting the database way too much. Default value is 10000 ms.
EDIT-CONFIG.JOB-LOCK-TIME-HELP: The time (in ms) that a job is locked by one job executor component. When the time is passed, but the job is not yet executed, the job can again be acquired by other job executor. This is to avoid that one failing job executor would halt job execution forever. Default value is 5 minutes (300000 ms)
EDIT-CONFIG.JOB-CORE-POOL-SIZE-HELP: The minimum amount of threads in the thread pool that are kept active for executing jobs. Only applicable for the default job executor.
EDIT-CONFIG.JOB-QUEUE-SIZE-HELP: The default job executor first acquires jobs and puts them on queue before executing them in a thread pool. This value determines how many jobs are kept on this queue. Only applicable for the default job executor (does not apply for Spring job executor for example or custom implementations).
EDIT-CONFIG.JOB-MAX-POOL-SIZE-HELP: The maximum amount of threads in the thread pool that are created for executing jobs. Only applicable for the default job executor.
EDIT-CONFIG.ENABLE-DB-POOL-HELP: Allows configuration of the connection pool of the datasource created by Alfresco Process Services. These settings are only applicable if Alfresco Process Services is responsible for creating the datasource (as opposed to jndi, for example) and has not received any Spring injections.
EDIT-CONFIG.JOB-MAX-CHECKOUT-TIME-HELP: The maximum time a connection can be used before it 'may' be given away again.
EDIT-CONFIG.JOB-MAX-WAIT-TIME-HELP: The time to wait before retrying to get a connection.
EDIT-CONFIG.ENABLE-MAIL-SERVER-INFO: This is only needed when using the email functionality in your business processes.
EDIT-CONFIG.MAIL-JNDI-NAME-INFO: Fill this in (ignoring the settings above) if the mailserver is configured in an application server and exposed through Jndi.
